title: Edward B. Quinn, PhD, MPH
text: I am a Data Scientist and a published health researcher. My PhD training was in epigenetics and health equity, where I used R to analyze over 400 million data points. In my spare time, I love to travel and watch mixed martial arts.

title: Using Virtual Environments in Python
text:
Make sure you are in the directory where you want to create a virtual environment.
Use the following code: python -m venv .venv
Activate the virtual environment using .\.venv\Scripts\activate
pip install whatever it is you need to install.
Export dependencies by using pip freeze >> requirements.txt
Deactivate the virtual environment by using deactivate
Make sure to add .venv to your .gitignore file before committing.





Pull the repo from github
Create a new virtual environment as described above.
Use the requirements.txt to file to recreate the virtual environment like so: pip install -r requirements.txt.

title: Data visualization in Python
text:
Using Seaborn to visualize progress in public health
Activate the virtual environment


Code
import polars as pl
import seaborn as sns




Code
df = pl.read_csv("https://data.cdc.gov/resource/6rkc-nb2q.csv")




Code
df.head()



shape: (5, 3)



year
leading_causes
age_adjusted_death_rate


i64
str
f64




1900
"Heart Disease"
265.4


1901
"Heart Disease"
272.6


1902
"Heart Disease"
285.2


1903
"Heart Disease"
304.5


1904
"Heart Disease"
331.5






The year column is an integer. Make a new column where the year is a date time.


Code
# Create a new datetime column by combining year with a default month and day
df = df.with_columns(
    (pl.col("year").cast(pl.Utf8) + "-01-01").str.strptime(pl.Date).alias("date")
)




Code
# Python code goes here
df.glimpse()


Rows: 595
Columns: 4
$ year                     <i64> 1900, 1901, 1902, 1903, 1904, 1905, 1906, 1907, 1908, 1909
$ leading_causes           <str> 'Heart Disease', 'Heart Disease', 'Heart Disease', 'Heart Disease', 'Heart Disease', 'Heart Disease', 'Heart Disease', 'Heart Disease', 'Heart Disease', 'Heart Disease'
$ age_adjusted_death_rate  <f64> 265.4, 272.6, 285.2, 304.5, 331.5, 327.8, 325.5, 356.5, 328.6, 329.2
$ date                    <date> 1900-01-01, 1901-01-01, 1902-01-01, 1903-01-01, 1904-01-01, 1905-01-01, 1906-01-01, 1907-01-01, 1908-01-01, 1909-01-01



Now make a single line chart for all leading causes of death.


Code
sns.lineplot(data = df, x = 'date', y = 'age_adjusted_death_rate', hue = 'leading_causes')











Code
# Python code goes here
print('hello python')

title: Data Visualization in R
text:
Visualizing heart disease death rates using ggplot2
The National Center of Health Statistics has published data on age-adjusted death rates for five leading causes of death in the United States between 1900 - 2018. Let’s look at visualization strategies to highlight different insights from the data. Shoutout to Albert Rapp’s YouTube video on linecharts. I learned a lot of this code from Albert’s excellent video tutorial.


Code
df <- read_csv("https://data.cdc.gov/resource/6rkc-nb2q.csv")

sysfonts::font_add_google('Merriweather')



# Important step to enable showtext font rendering!
showtext_auto()




Code
title_text <- 'It took 100 years for the <span style = "color:#87CEEB">**Heart Disease Death Rate**</span> <br> to recover to levels observed in 1900'

df |> 
  filter(leading_causes == "Heart Disease") |> 
ggplot(aes(year, age_adjusted_death_rate, color = leading_causes)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +
  labs(title = "Major causes of mortality") +
  theme_minimal(
    base_size = 24,
    base_family = 'Merriweather'
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    y = element_blank(),
    title = title_text,
    subtitle = "Age-Adjusted Death Rate (per 100,000)",
    caption = "Source: National Center for Health Statistics"
  ) +
  gghighlight(
    leading_causes == "Heart Disease",
    year <= 2000,
    use_direct_label = FALSE,
    use_group_by = FALSE,
    unhighlighted_params = list(color = "grey80", linewidth = 1)
  ) +
  annotate(
    'text',
    x = 1992,
    y = 550,
    size = 5.5,
    label = "Heart Disease Death Rate",
    fontface = "bold",
    color = "skyblue2"
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(values = "skyblue2") +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major = element_line(linewidth = 0.5, linetype = 2),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    text = element_text(color = "grey20"),
    axis.text = element_text(color = "grey40"),
    plot.title = ggtext::element_markdown(color = "grey20", family = "Merriweather"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(
      color = "grey30",
      size = rel(0.8),
      margin = margin(b=8, unit = 'mm')
    ),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = rel(0.6), color = "grey20")
  ) +
  annotate(
    'segment',
    x = 1900,
    xend = 2000,
    y = 265,
    yend = 265,
    linetype = 2,
    linewidth = 1,
    color = "grey10"
  )

title: renv Cheatsheet
text:
An renv cheatsheet

Use renv::init() to start a brand new project. This creates an renv.lock file listing packages and versions.
Install packages as normal using install.packages()
Occasionally use renv::snapshot() to capture updates to your virtual environment within the renv.lock file
After you finish a post, use renv::snapshot() one last time.
Copy the renv.lock file into the root directory for the particular post you just finished. cp renv.lock path_to_blog_post_directory/
Add the code chunk below which specifies using the local renv.lock file using renv::use(lockfile = "renv.lock")

title: Using Virtual Environments in Python
text:
Make sure you are in the directory where you want to create a virtual environment.
Use the following code: python -m venv env
Activate the virtual environment using .\env\Scripts\activate
pip install whatever it is you need to install.
Export dependencies by using pip freeze >> requirements.txt
Deactivate the virtual environment by using deactivate
Make sure to add .venv to your .gitignore file before committing.





Pull the repo from github
Create a new virtual environment as described above.
Use the requirements.txt to file to recreate the virtual environment like so: pip install -r requirements.txt.
